thread.title: Daredevil holidaymaker snapped in one of the most dizzying selfies of all time... while paragliding 6,550 FEET above Turkey's Mediterranean coast
thread.title_full: Daredevil holidaymaker snapped in one of the most dizzying selfies of all time... while paragliding 6,550 FEET above Turkey's Mediterranean coast | Daily Mail Online

author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: Daredevil holidaymaker snapped in one of the most dizzying selfies of all time... while paragliding 6,550 FEET above Turkey's Mediterranean coast
text:
43 shares 16
View
comments
A British holidaymaker has been captured in one of the most dizzying selfies of all time – while soaring through the sky at a stomach-churning altitude of 6,550ft.
Armed with a selfie stick, an instructor snapped these astonishing photos of Lauren Newell, from Broseley, Shropshire, as she completed the second highest paraglide in the world while on holiday in Turkey.
The daredevil tourist’s jaw-dropping selfies were taken high above the sea in Oludeniz, but she insists the experience wasn’t as scary as one would think.
An instructor snapped this astonishing photos of Lauren Newell as she completed the second highest paraglide in the world
The daredevil tourist’s jaw-dropping selfies were taken high above the sea in Oludeniz, a village on the Mediterranean coast
Lauren, 20, decided to go on the wild ride while staying at a resort on Turkey’s south-west coast with her boyfriend, Mark Wigley, also 20.
Lauren, who is studying French and Spanish at the University of Manchester, said: ‘The beach and the lagoon are incredibly beautiful.
 Next Iceland’s breathtaking beauty: From an eye-popping waterfall... How I spent my (awkward) family summer holiday: Website... 'They’re foreign tourists. You’re blatantly ripping them... ‘The paraglide itself wasn't as scary as we were expecting it was actually extremely peaceful. It felt a bit like sitting in a very windy chair.’
Paragliding, also known as parapenting, involves soaring through the sky as the rider and an instructor sit in a harness below a wing that looks like a long parachute.
Lauren said the experience wasn't as scary as it looks, as it was 'extremely peaceful and felt a bit like sitting in a very windy chair'
The 20-year-old student said the most frightening part of the experience was the minibus ride to the top of the mountain
Lauren said: ‘We jumped at about 9am, which was recommended to avoid the afternoon mist from the mountain obscuring the view.
‘The most frightening part was the minibus to the top, as the driver threw it around really tight corners with a sheer drop down the side.
‘We weren't sure if we were going to make it to the top but it did help get the adrenaline going.
‘When we got there, I only turned for a split second to be attached to my harness and when I turned around Mark was already up in the air and sailing down.
Lauren and her boyfriend, Mark Wigley, (pictured with their instructor) went on the wild ride while staying at a resort in Turkey
‘I went from extremely excited to nervous to excited again before take-off, but as soon as we were in the air it was really calm.
‘It was about a 20 minute journey from the jump to landing near the beach with a few 360 degree spins in between. It made my stomach lurch but it was amazing.’
Lauren now has her sights set on completing the world's highest paraglide in South Africa as her next challenge.
The thrill for adventure is in Lauren's blood – her great-great-grandfather was the first British man to skydive with a parachute.
